title: How to Make a Crossover Cable from One Standard Ethernet Cable

steps.headline: Find a standard Ethernet cable you don't use for anything.
steps.description: With this guide, you will be able to use a long 100 feet (30.5 m). cable, or a shorter size, whatever your needs require.

steps.headline: Towards one end of the cable, cut open a slit a few inches long.
steps.description: Be careful not to damage the wiring inside the cable or cut yourself.

steps.headline: Peel back and remove the cable casing.
steps.description: This will leave the inner wiring exposed. Examine how the wiring is twisted together and note the colors of the wires. For this project, we will be cutting the colored wires (green, orange, white-green, white-orange) and leaving the other wires in place as usual.

steps.headline: Cut the green, orange, white-green and the white-orange.
steps.description: The other wires will be left as-is.

steps.headline: With the wires cut, work now one-by-one.
On Side "A" we will call it, connect the green stripped end to the orange stripped end on Side "B".
steps.description: Twist the wires together, and mend with electrical or another kind of tape. If you have a soldering iron, you can optionally solder the leads together.

steps.headline: You now have one step of your crossover wire completed.
Just as we connected the orange and green wires for one side of our crossover cable, lets now repeat the process with the final two wires.
On Side "A", join the green-white wire to the orange-white wire on Side "B".
steps.description: Twist the wires together and fix with tape. Again, if you prefer, you can solder the wires together as opposed to twisting them together.

steps.headline: Join the remaining wires.
steps.description: Join the orange-white wire on Side "A", with the green-white wire on Side "B". Fashion the wires with tape or solder.

steps.headline: Clean the cable up.
Admire your new, home made crossover cable!

text:
Find a standard Ethernet cable you don't use for anything. With this guide, you will be able to use a long 100 feet (30.5 m). cable, or a shorter size, whatever your needs require. Towards one end of the cable, cut open a slit a few inches long. Be careful not to damage the wiring inside the cable or cut yourself. Peel back and remove the cable casing. This will leave the inner wiring exposed. Examine how the wiring is twisted together and note the colors of the wires. For this project, we will be cutting the colored wires (green, orange, white-green, white-orange) and leaving the other wires in place as usual. Cut the green, orange, white-green and the white-orange. The other wires will be left as-is. With the wires cut, work now one-by-one. First, strip the orange wire on both cut sides down. (approx. 1/4 or 1/2 inch){"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} After both ends of the orange wire has been stripped, strip both ends of the green wire down. (approx. 1/4 or 1/2 inch){"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} On Side "A" we will call it, connect the green stripped end to the orange stripped end on Side "B". Twist the wires together, and mend with electrical or another kind of tape. If you have a soldering iron, you can optionally solder the leads together. You now have one step of your crossover wire completed. Lets continue on. Just as we connected the orange and green wires for one side of our crossover cable, lets now repeat the process with the final two wires. Start by stripping the green-white wires. (once again, approx. 1/4 or 1/2 inch){"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Repeat the wire stripping on orange-white wires. (once again, approx. 1/4 or 1/2 inch){"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-8Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} On Side "A", join the green-white wire to the orange-white wire on Side "B". Twist the wires together and fix with tape. Again, if you prefer, you can solder the wires together as opposed to twisting them together. Join the remaining wires. Join the orange-white wire on Side "A", with the green-white wire on Side "B". Fashion the wires with tape or solder. Clean the cable up. Note the direction that the wiring in the cable case is twisting. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Holding the cable in your hands, twist the cable in the same way as the internal wiring is twisted. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Keep the wire twisted, and close it up with tape or shrink-wrap. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet3.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet3.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Crossover-Cable-from-One-Standard-Ethernet-Cable-Step-11Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Admire your new, home made crossover cable!
tyn_model: electrical or another kind of tape
